subject: Design
title: Wallpaper: Pattern as Poison
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Wallpaper: Pattern as Poison.

hook.text: In the 1800s, green wallpaper was wildly popular. It was also slowly poisoning the people who lived with it.

buildup.text: Scheele's Green, a vivid pigment, contained arsenic. Damp conditions released toxic gas from the walls.

discovery.text: Napoleon may have died partly from arsenic in his green wallpaper on St. Helena.

twist.text: William Morris, the most famous wallpaper designer, knew about the danger but his family's mine produced arsenic.

climax.text: Wallpaper history shows that design choices can have hidden consequences decades after installation.

punchline.text: The most beautiful wall covering in history was also the most deadly.

quiz.question: What made Victorian green wallpaper dangerous?
